page.lettertext:
fol.344r
Belgia 1592 October 25
May it please yo
r
good L. With your letters
of
e 7 and 8 of this moneth, w
ch
were delivered
unto me
e 18 I receaved one from her
Ma
tie
to
the
General states
, w
ch
I presented unto them at
their next assemblie, and solicited her demaund,
for
e sending of their shipping to
e coast of
Bri-
taine
. Their answear therunto I have sent
heereinclosed, tending all to this effect,
at they have
taken those affaires as muche to hart as was possi-
Men sending to
Britaine
ble: that all
e last sommer, they expected very
carefully her Hig
es
resolution, upon their offers [.]
that behalf, w
ch
they had signified unto me, and I
reported to yo
r
L. in my letters of
e 21 of Apr[il]
and 16 of July: that as then they had
e meanes
to perfourme as muche as they had offered: but
understanding nothing from her Ma
tie
have im-
ploied those meanes in other exploites, and shall
not possibly be able, to obtene of
e Provinces an[y]
further contribution, till
e spring of
e yere. And
besides they must be forced, for want of victuals
and other provisions, to revoke those other shippes
w
ch
they have at this p
nt
, on
e coast of Britaine.
This day
M
r
Buzenval
receaved l
res
from
e
King,
to make a motion to
e states, like
that of her Ma
tie
. I have acquainted him at lar[ge]
w
t
their answear unto me, to prepare him thereby
to meete w
t
their objections in proposing his maters.
He is willed by
e King, to declare unto them,
at
there hath passed a Contract between him and cer
taine inhabitants of
Gasconie
and
Guien
, and the
towne of
Rochel
, who have lately undertaken
fol.344v
upon certaine couvenants, to maintene 20 shippes
very thorowly fournished, for defense of these coastes,
to w
ch
e states are required to joine some further
strength. I will certifie yo
r
L. w
at
answear
shall be made, though I see no likelihood of a better,
then is given to her Ma
tie
. Astouching
the often staies of
e Companies of foote, w
ch
I doubte
are yet detened by a contrary winde, I hope yo
r
L. is certified from
e
Gouverno
r
of
Flushing,
and
S
r
Francis Vere
: who remaine in
e place, where
e companies are, and, as I am informed, have
receaved in charge some other addresses, then have
bin by any imparted to me. For I protest unto
yo
r
L. of her Hig
es
resolution, to have
e souldi-
ers to be shipped for
Jersey,
and not for
Caen,
I have onely heard a litle by a privat frindes
letter, and
at very barely and imperfectly:
at I knowe not in particular, w
at
hath bin written
about it, not w
at
order there is taken for
e ac-
complishing therof. Whiche I signifie so unto
yo
w
, to
e end yo
r
L. may consider,
at by rea-
son of my being so farre from Flushing, and my
want of intelligence of suche alterations, I can
nether give advise in
e assisting of others, no[r]
advertise yo
r
L. of those affaires of
e footeba[nds.]
It hath also enforced me, to delay
e dispat[che]
of
e company of horse, a great deale longer [then]
I would. For having signified by a letter [of the]
21 of Sep
t
for w
at
occasions of
e Contrey [could]
not urge
S
r
Nicholas Parker
, to embarke himse[lf]
presently, and having had therunto no answear [ther]un[to]
fol.345r
untill nowe, nor no direction for changing the
place of
e Rendevous, it cause me to doubt
at
the horsband should be staied, and therfor knewe
not howe to deale, w
t
out some warrant in other
sort: w
ch
though yo
r
L. hath sent, yet
e place of
e Rendevous is not mentioned unto me.
That at first I gave eare to Count Maurices in-
tercession, in suffering
e horsband to continue heere
in service, yo
r
L. will vouchesafe to make the
best of
at proceeding, in yo
r
dealing w
t
her
Hig
es
. For it was at
e instance of
e Count
and all
e contrey, for a very short time, and
for a speciall exploit. There were also suche im-
pediments, as yo
r
L. did approve: for w
ch
the
company of necessitie should be forced for a time
to remaine in the contrey. W
t
all I understood
then presently after, and nowe I doe finde
it to be true by experience,
at howsoever I had
resolved,
e Count and
e states, w
ch
were
in
e army, were determined fully to stay
e
company in
e Campe. I hope
at
yo
r
L. hath alwaies perceaved,
at I was
never in my actions a pleaser of this people,
but where I thought it might redound to
e
service of her Ma
tie
. For
e furtherance wherof
it can not otherwise be chosen, but according
to
e occasions, I must vary very often from
the Articles of my charge: w
ch
yet I never did
hitherto, but it turned in
e end to
e advantage
of her purpose. And where her Hig
es
fol.345v
is displeased for
e numbers of
horsbandes
strangers
inter-
tened in
e horsbandes, if it should be under-
tood, to come by my default, I would humbly be-
seeche yo
w
to calle to remembrance, w
at
I plea-
ded for my self in my letter to yo
r
L.
e 10 of Ja
n
last: upon an other like complaint of
e weake-
nes of
e companies sent into
Normandie
. For
e causes then alleaged, I hope I shall not need
to be presently troblesome. I was never yet wil-
led, sins I came to this place, to take any kind of
charge of looking to
e Musters. I was never
made acquainted by
e way of any letter, or co-
pie of any letter, w
t
e orders sette downe by
my
LL.
of
e Councel: and yet they have bin
renued at sundrie times, and every time sent
to every Englishe Gouverno
r
. If I had bin com-
maunded to deale in those affaires, upon receat
of some instruction, I would not have failed, to
have done my duty thorowly. Howbeit I doe
not understand, but
at
e Commissaries certifi-
cats are continually sent home, and
e state of
every bande made knowen unto them,
at are
appointed expressely to examine those maters
and have alwaies there
e meanes, both to shew
them to yo
r
L. and to to seeke redresse for a[ny]
abuses. And namely for
e band of S
r
[Nicholas]
Parker, although it hath passed
e rest, in n[om-]
ber, strength, and fourniture, yet notice h[ath]
bin given to
S
r
Thomas Wilkes
by
M
r
Alle[n
the]
Commissary, aswell by his muster rolles, and [.]
of warrants, as otherwise,
at his troupe w[.]
fol.346r
of strangers. And being told by
e Commissarie,
at
by her Ma
ties
orders, he could be allowed but one-
ly six, he answeared for himself,
at he had li-
cense for more from my LL. of
e Councell.
His company is nowe in garrison at
Duis-
bourgh
: but I have earnestly moved bothe
e Gene-
rall states and
e
Councel
, to give their pasport
and licence for his comming to
Berghen
, where
S
r
John Poley
is in garrison, and where according
to
e order prescribed by her Ma
tie
he may supplie
his deficients out of
e troupe of S
r
John Poley,
and make his other commutations both of horses
and horsmen, and also presently embarke his
souldiers for
Britaine
. I made my motion
first to
e Councel of Estate, as to whome it be-
longed by vertue of
e Contract, to give di-
rection in suche affaires. But because it concer-
ned
e removing of a company out of this c
o
trey,
they refused to take order, w
t
out
e leave and
assent of
e General states: to whome
ei sent
for advise. The states, for
at her Ma
tie
had
not written unto them about it, required one
to exhibit an Act of my hand, and to notifie ther-
by,
at it was her Hig
es
pleasure: w
ch
I perfour-
med immediatly. I should but trouble yo
r
L.
w
t
a needeles rehersal of all
e meetinges, and
debates, and sendinges too and fro,
at were used
in this mater. But
e states in c
o
clusion did
not onely make denial, of graunting their Pas-
port for removal of
e company, but enjoined
the Councel and
Count Maurice
(who hath c
o
monly
fol.346v
usurped, to give his patents in suche cases) not to
deale in
e mater. I urged earnestly to knowe,
e reason of
at proceeding, considering my demaund
was but onely for a company, and they had suffered
already 16 others to passe, and likewise those the
last yere,
at were sent for Normandie, without
suche open opposition. I doubted
e issue
the
would be this,
at her Ma
tie
would be moved, to re
voke all
e rest. Notw
t
standing all my urging,
I could gette no other reason, but
at they could not
permitte it. But when I mentioned
e revoking of
e rest of
e horsmen, Count Maurice replied, That
he could rather wishe it were p
nt
ly done, then to
tary till
e spring, and then to have them on the
soddaine to be called away, when
e contrey
should relie upon
e benefit of their service. Wher-
to I answeared againe,
at there had never no
suche course bin taken by her Ma
tie
. They had
alwaies had warning sufficient before, and if
then after they would in hand w
t
some enter-
prise a freshe,
e fault was in themselves, if
they were not assisted. And as for
e horsband
of S
r
Nicholas Parker, if they would not permitte
him to passe by good order, I would endevo
r
[what]
I could to effect it otherwise: and if any [in-]
convenience ensued upon it, it rested in the [.]
to satisfie
e contrey. Moreov[er I]
intreated
e Councel both then and before [at]
several times, to prohibit their captaines by so[me]
publike edict, to receave any Englishe sould[iers]
at should goe from these Captaines, w
ch
were [.]
fol.347r
for Britaine. Whereto
ei made answear, That
they could not constraine any souldier of this con-
trey: and as for those of
e Englishe nation,
at
should runne from their Captaines, and put them-
selves in service heere in
e pay of
e Contrey,
ei
used a kinde of cunning, in counterfaiting of
Dutche names, and could be hardly discovered by
their Commissaries in
e Musters. And besides by
Placcartes already published, it was forbidden to
any Dutche Captaine, to intertene any stranger,
of w
at
nation soever. Upon these kin[des]
of answears, I can not yet resolve, in w
at
sort
I should proceede, to drawe away
e horsband.
I doubt very muche it will not prevaile, to
stoppe their weekely lendinges. Of force they must
have meanes, for themselves and their horses. And
if they live upon
e towne, where they lie nowe
in garrison, no doubt their horses will be staied
till restitution shall be made. Againe if the
state will seeme to uphold
e Dutche souldier in
refusing to goe for Britaine, I can not perceave
by any enquirie,
at bothe
e companies together
of S
r
Nicholas Parker and S
r
John Poley, are able to
fournishe a full company of Englishe horsmen.
And although S
r
Nicholas Parkers be
e strongest of
the fower companies, and was very complete
e
beginning of this sommer:
and
yet nowe I heare
at
his numbers are very muche diminished: and
for
e other three, they are said to be farre weaker
then S
r
Nicholas Parkers: so as some of them, I doubt,
fol.347v
have scarcely half their number. The
very best way,
at I can thinke upon presently,
to procure
e company a passage, is to cause
e officer
of
e T
re
r, to send those shippes,
at shall be [hired]
by him for transportation of them, to come up to
e Vaert by
Utrecht
, and to cause S
r
Nicholas Parker,
to come thither w
t
his horses. W
ch
yet is a mater full of
difficultie and danger, by reason of
e officers and
boores of
e contrey, w
ch
are wont for
e most, to
stoppe
e passage of any company,
at comes without
a passeport: and also often times, for a very
smalle misdemeanor of any common souldier, to
putte themeslves in armes, and to invade
e whole
troupe. The report going heere,
that divers boates of this contrey, and some mes-
sengers w
t
letters directed for England, have late-
ly miscaried, because I am uncertaine, whether
any of those letters,
at I have written to yo
r
L.
have bin lost by suche accidents, I have sent
e copie
heere of one above
e rest, w
ch
I writte
e 10 of
this moneth, and to my understanding is most
material. I am lastly to becomme
an humble suito
r
to yo
r
L.
at it would stand
with yo
r
honorable favo
r
to put her Ma
tie
in re-
membrance of my long being heere, for fower ye[res]
together: and that in respect of her Hig
es
b[usi-]
nes, I could never be better spared, nor ha[ve]
never greater cause, in respect of mine ow[ne estate]
whiche is wholy confused, and groweth w[.]
every day, by meanes of mine absence. Of d[ivers]
hopes that I have had, through
e answeares [from yo
r
]
fol.348r
yo
r
L. to my former petitions,
e last was
differred to
e end of this sommer: whiche the
sooner yo
w
shall be pleased to effect w
t
her Hig
es
the more I shall be bound, to acknowledge yo
r
goodnes, being otherwise most bound for many
singular occasions.
And so I take my humble
leave. From
e Hage. Oc
t
25 1592
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
For
at I want at this present a convenient
messenger, I have intreated this bearer, to cary
this letter, and to make as muche hast, as
e
winde will permitte: wherein I trust he will
not faile. Having also spoken w
t
M
r
Buzenval
, sins my letter was written and sins
his being w
t
e states, he hath told me, that
their answear to his motion, is
e same as they
give to her Ma
ties
l
re
, That till
e spring
they can doe nothing.
